Our President is a bigot and I commend my colleagues for continuing to stand up to him and fight for justice.

As an African-American man, I’ve been called a number of terrible words throughout my life just because the color of my skin. I know what is racist and what is not — and being told to go back to your own country is up there with being called the n-word.
Americans elected by their fellow Americans to represent them are right where they belong: in Congress. Racism has no place in our country or in the President’s Twitter feed.

The problems here go beyond a lack of resources. Treating others with respect is free. After today I am more determined than ever to ensure that Congress exercise it's oversight responsibilities and to see that America create an immigration system worthy of our values. (5/5)

While we were visiting, news also broke that thousands of Border Agents were part of a secret Facebook group where members regularly posted offensive, racist, and sexist comments about the migrants in their custody, as well as members of Congress. (4/5)

Nevertheless, we found children barely older than toddlers in cells; families that had been separated from one another; holding centers that were little more than animal sheds, with chainlink fences and pad-locks used to lock up men, women, and children. (3/5)
First of all, I know that what we saw, as members of Congress on a scheduled visit planned in advance, must be far from the worst conditions faced by migrants in Border Patrol custody. (2/5)

Over the past several weeks, we've heard disturbing reports of conditions faced by migrant children in U.S. government custody. Today, my colleagues and I traveled to El Paso, Texas to see for ourselves. What we found was awful. (1/5) pic.twitter.com/nWFAHWpdvl
I just left the Clint Border Patrol station, along with several of my colleagues. What I found wasn’t good. #DemsAtTheBorder pic.twitter.com/SuRZZKWCqD

Today I am joining several of my colleagues in inspecting Border Patrol Stations near El Paso where hundreds of children have been held. Cruelty should never be an instrument of our immigration policy. pic.twitter.com/jMAaKgSaZ4
